Lewis fulfills potential with memorable win

06/01/2011

Adrian Lewis clinched the 2011 Ladbrokes.com World Darts Championship on Monday, Sam Morgan reviews the action (Thumbnail credit Adrian Lewis, the 2011 Ladbrokes.com World Darts Championships winner. Image: sachab via Flickr Creative Commons)

Image by

By undefined undefined

Adrian Lewis claimed the 2011 Ladbrokes.com World Darts Championship in a thrilling final at Alexandra Palace in London on Monday. Lewis' impressive high averages and consistency in hitting the doubles saw him defeat Gary Anderson 7-5. An electric start to proceedings was provided when, in just the third leg of the first set, Lewis produced the first nine-darter ever recorded in a World Championship final. In the blink of an eye Lewis had already captured the first set and placed doubt among those who, like Eric Bristow and Rod Harrington, seemed certain of an Anderson victory. By snatching the first two legs of the second set - making it five legs in a row - Lewis made it clear that his scintillating start was no accident. With every one of Lewis' darts that landed in the treble-twenty, Anderson's face grew taut and his throwing style more and more rigid, snatching instead of releasing. The 'Flying Scotsman' was struggling to take off, his lips tight, cursing every one of his missed doubles, and he looked out of shape next to the loose, relaxed Lewis. The quick rhythm of the man from Stoke did not give Anderson time to breathe and he stormed to a 2-0 advantage. Anderson returned in the third set looking more his own man. Having slowed the pace of the match down he eventually managed to land a dart in the bed of the double-two to take the first leg of the third set and showed his opponent that he, too, was capable of darts of the very highest quality with a measured 136 checkout. By the fourth set you got the sense that Lewis and Anderson were feeding off each other. If one scored a maximum so did the other. If Anderson missed a couple of doubles - like in the second leg of this set - then Lewis did too. This was a real topsy-turvy affair and as much as the game will be remembered for Lewis having won it, each player was guilty of throwing away crucial legs: a 76 checkout from Lewis made Anderson pay for a missed double-top and gave 'Jackpot' a 3-1 lead. Two sets down things were looking decidedly grim for Anderson in the fifth set. The Scotsman's double success rate was down to thirty percent and he was lucky to be allowed five darts - courtesy of a series of blunders from Lewis - to finally get double-ten - a double that would, as it turned out, plague him all night. Anderson ever resilient, however, clawed his way back into the match at 3-2. It did not really come as any surprise that Anderson's best checkout came courtesy of the bullseye rather than a double. Against the throw Anderson needed only three darts to score 164 and followed this with a decent checkout of 86 to level the match at 3-3. If there was one area of concern for Anderson's fans before the game then it would have been his shakiness at landing a double. These fears surfaced again in the seventh set when Lewis secured a crucial double-five against the pace of play to snatch the point from under Anderson's nose. By this point Lewis seemed oblivious to the situation. His expression, his mannerisms, and his rhythm rarely altered. Not once did his eyes light up at the chance of a high checkout and not once did they fixate the ground in disgust at a poor throw. Indeed, when Lewis showed his doggedness by securing a 97 checkout and then grinding out a finish on double-eighteen, he showed he had the mettle to see out this match; only two more sets were needed when it stood in his favour at 5-3. The incredibly high standard from both players remained even into the nerve-testing final stages, but you got the sense that if Lewis could win the ninth set against Anderson's throw then the Championship would be his. 'Jackpot' bombarded the trebles and his onslaught of 180s and 177s was too much for the Scotsman who lost the set to make it 6-3 to the fan favourite. This match will be remembered as one of the all-time greats of PDC history but, up until this point, the only thing missing from the Hollywood-script was the spirited comeback. Anderson did his best to provide. He broke Lewis' throw to make it 6-4 and in the eleventh set managed to successfully guide his dart into the double-five to put himself within touching distance of his opponent. The previously unflappable Lewis appeared to be cracking at the edges and, for a brief moment, it looked as if the experience of Anderson may see him through. But Lewis is made of stern stuff: he has been trained by fifteen time World Champion Phil Taylor since he was a teenager and no doubt Taylor has nurtured and encouraged Lewis' raw talent and passed on his own vast knowledge of how to handle the pressure of a final. It proved invaluable when two of Lewis' darts fell out of the treble-eighteen in the third leg of the twelfth set, leaving him to pick up one hundred and eight points off the floor. The misfortune did little to derail the twenty five year-old's concentration, however, and he cleaned up the final set 3-0 to win 7-5 overall and claim his first major triumph. In one of the most open championships in years Lewis and Anderson provided one of the best finals ever seen. While Adrian Lewis lets his victory sink in, however, bigger storms are brewing in the PDC. Phil Taylor's early exit, Raymond van Barneveld's lack of form, and James Wade's poor showing have fans pondering 'Is their era of domination over?'. One cannot help but feel that it is significant that it should be Taylor's protege who claims the most coveted title in darts this year. With many seeing this championship as the passing of the torch, the game's heavyweights will have to prove that they still have the ability to remain at the top of professional darts.
